title: Santo Jeger

sentences.sentence: Santo Wayburn Jeger (20 May 1898 – 24 September 1953) was a British Labour Party politician who served as a Member of Parliament (MP) from 1945 until his death
Born in London, Jeger attended University College, Cardiff and the London and St Mary's Hospitals
As a doctor, Jeger was a founder of the Socialist Medical Association

He served as a councillor on Shoreditch Borough Council from 1925 and was Mayor of the Borough 1929–1930 and the Chairman of the Borough's public health committee for six years, establishing a number of clinics and public health schemes
He represented Shoreditch on the Metropolitan Boroughs Standing Joint Committee
Jeger was elected to the London County Council in 1931, serving until 1946. He was active in providing medical aid to the Republicans in the Spanish Civil War
Jeger stood for Parliament without success in 1935 general election in St Pancras South East but won the seat at the 1945 general election
He was elected in the two subsequent elections in 1950 and 1951 for the new seat of Holborn and St Pancras South
Jeger died in 1953 at the age of 55, and his widow, Lena Jeger, succeeded him as the member of parliament in the ensuing by-election
